metadata.title: ‡§Ü‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§™‡§°‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó (Getting Sick Experiment)
metadata.subject: Marathi
metadata.description: A humorous Marathi story about a child who tries desperately to get sick so they can skip an upcoming exam. The child eats cold things, stands in the rain, stays up all night ‚Äî but their body stubbornly stays perfectly healthy! The story ends with the child having to go to school and take the exam. The humour comes from the gap between the child's desperate efforts and the body's natural resilience. The chapter introduces grammar: ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•á (Postpositions) ‚Äî words used after nouns to show spatial or relational connections, like ‡§µ‡§∞ (on), ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä (under), ‡§ú‡§µ‡§≥ (near), ‡§Ü‡§§ (inside).

preAssessment.question: Why does the child in the story try to get sick?

options.A: To avoid helping with household chores
options.B: To get out of going to school and avoid an upcoming exam
options.C: To get sympathy and gifts from parents

options.B: Postpositions ‚Äî words used AFTER nouns to show relationships

preAssessment.question: What is the Marathi postposition for 'on top of' or 'on'?
What is the humorous message of the story '‡§Ü‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§™‡§°‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó'?

options.A: Getting sick is easy if you try hard enough
options.B: The body is designed to stay healthy ‚Äî it is hard to get sick on purpose!
options.D: Parents always know when children are faking sickness

preAssessment.question: The word '‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ó‡•á' (mage) as a Marathi postposition means:

concepts.title: Story Summary ‚Äî The Failed Experiment
concepts.content: The story is told with gentle, funny irony. A student has an exam the next day and absolutely does not want to take it. The child hatches a plan: get sick tonight, so that tomorrow's absence is completely justified! The 'experiment' begins: eating cold ice cream, drinking icy water, standing barefoot in the rain, sleeping near the open window, staying up all night. Despite all these determined efforts, the child wakes up the next morning completely healthy ‚Äî rested, energetic, and with no choice but to go to school. The story is a comedy of the human body's natural defences frustrating the child's best-laid plans.

examples.text: Eating cold ice cream and icy water ‚Äî the child hopes to catch a cold or upset stomach.
Standing in the rain barefoot ‚Äî another classic 'method' children try to get sick.
Staying up all night near an open window ‚Äî hoping to catch a chill.
The ironic result: wakes up perfectly healthy, refreshed, and has to go to school!

keyPoints: The story uses humour (‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ã‡§¶) to make a serious point ‚Äî the body naturally resists illness.
Every child will relate to the desperate feeling of wanting to avoid an exam!
The story is written in first-person style ‚Äî the narrator is also the child protagonist.
The title '‡§Ü‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§™‡§°‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó' (Experiment in Getting Sick) sets up the ironic experiment.
The climax: despite all efforts, the body remains stubbornly healthy ‚Äî nature defeats the plan.
concepts.funFact: The story cleverly references a real fact: children try many methods to get sick but rarely succeed because the immune system is designed to fight off common threats quickly. In fact, some of the things the child does (like getting fresh air near an open window) might actually be HEALTHY!
concepts.textbookRef: Chapter 7, Pages 18-25 ‚Äî Maharashtra Board 7th Grade Marathi (Second Language)

concepts.title: Why the Experiment Fails ‚Äî The Body's Defences
concepts.content: The story teaches us something important about human biology: the body is designed to maintain health (homeostasis). Our immune system is constantly working to fight off bacteria and viruses. Getting sick requires exposure to specific germs ‚Äî you can't get sick just by eating ice cream or standing in rain if your immune system is working well. Common cold is caused by rhinovirus ‚Äî not by cold weather itself (though cold conditions can weaken some defences). The story humorously shows that the body is not a machine you can break on command ‚Äî it has its own intelligence and defence systems.

examples.text: Getting sick requires exposure to specific germs (viruses or bacteria) ‚Äî not just cold weather.
A healthy child's immune system fights off most threats quickly ‚Äî within hours in many cases.
Cold weather doesn't directly cause colds ‚Äî the rhinovirus (cold virus) does. Cold weather may reduce some defences, but a healthy person resists it.
Staying up all night might make you tired ‚Äî but your immune system doesn't just switch off overnight.

keyPoints: The immune system (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä) is the body's defence against disease ‚Äî it works 24 hours.
Sickness is caused by specific germs (viruses, bacteria) ‚Äî not simply by being cold or wet.
The body has natural mechanisms to maintain health ‚Äî this is called homeostasis.
Eating ice cream or standing in rain won't make you sick if you have good immunity.
The story uses this biological fact to create the comedy ‚Äî the experiment always fails!
concepts.funFact: The famous saying 'Laughter is the best medicine' has scientific backing! Research shows that laughter boosts the immune system, reduces stress hormones, and increases immune cells. So reading this funny story is literally good for your health!
concepts.textbookRef: Chapter 7, Pages 19-22 ‚Äî Health and body's defences

concepts.title: Health and Immunity
concepts.content: The story, through humour, gives us a chance to think about health and immunity. Good health is built through: regular sleep (‡§ù‡•ã‡§™), good nutrition (‡§™‡•ã‡§∑‡§£), exercise (‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ), hygiene (‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§æ), and avoiding harmful habits. The immune system is strengthened by: eating fruits and vegetables (especially Vitamin C rich foods like amla/‡§Ü‡§µ‡§≥‡§æ, oranges/‡§∏‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä), staying hydrated, regular physical activity, and adequate sleep. Conversely, the immune system is weakened by: lack of sleep, poor diet, stress, smoking, and excessive sugar intake. The child in the story ironically does things (staying up all night, eating cold things) that weaken immunity!

examples.text: Good sleep (8 hours for children): essential for immune system repair and strengthening.
Vitamin C (oranges, lemons, amla/‡§Ü‡§µ‡§≥‡§æ) strengthens the immune system ‚Äî Maharashtra is famous for Nagpur oranges!
Daily exercise: even 30 minutes of outdoor play boosts immunity significantly.
Hand washing (‡§π‡§æ‡§§ ‡§ß‡•Å‡§£‡•á): the single most effective way to prevent the spread of germs ‚Äî simple but powerful.

keyPoints: Immune system (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä) = the body's defence against illness.
Strengthens immunity: sleep, exercise, fruits/vegetables, hydration, hygiene.
Weakens immunity: sleep deprivation, poor diet, stress, lack of exercise.
Ironically, what the child in the story does (staying up late, cold food) is exactly what weakens immunity long-term.
Maharashtra health connection: Nagpur oranges (rich in Vitamin C) are famous for their immune-boosting properties!
concepts.funFact: Nagpur, Maharashtra, is called the 'Orange City' (‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§®‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ä) ‚Äî it is one of India's largest orange producers. Maharashtra's Vidarbha region produces millions of tonnes of oranges every year. Oranges are rich in Vitamin C, which is essential for a strong immune system. So Nagpur oranges are literally 'health' from Maharashtra!

concepts.title: Grammar: ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•á (Postpositions) ‚Äî Definition
concepts.content: In Marathi grammar, '‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•á' (Shabdayogi Avyaye) are postpositions ‚Äî words placed AFTER a noun to show the relationship between that noun and other parts of the sentence. In English, these would be prepositions (words like on, under, near, inside), but in Marathi they come AFTER the noun, not before ‚Äî making them 'postpositions.' The word '‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä' = ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶ (word) + ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä (joining/connecting). So a ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø is a word that connects/joins to another word to show a relationship. Examples: '‡§ü‡•á‡§¨‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞' (on the table) = ‡§ü‡•á‡§¨‡§≤ (table) + ‡§µ‡§∞ (on). '‡§ò‡§∞‡§æ‡§§' (inside the house) = ‡§ò‡§∞ (house) + ‡§Ü‡§§ (inside).

examples.text: '‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡§æ ‡§ò‡§∞‡§æ‡§§ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á' ‚Äî The boy is INSIDE the house. '‡§Ü‡§§' (inside) comes after '‡§ò‡§∞'.
'‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ú‡§∞ ‡§ù‡§æ‡§°‡§æ‡§ú‡§µ‡§≥ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á' ‚Äî The cat is NEAR the tree. '‡§ú‡§µ‡§≥' (near) comes after '‡§ù‡§æ‡§°'.
'‡§™‡§ø‡§∂‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§ñ‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡•Ä‡§ñ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á' ‚Äî The bag is UNDER the chair. '‡§ñ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä' (under/below) comes after '‡§ñ‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡•Ä'.

keyPoints: ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•á are Marathi postpositions ‚Äî they come AFTER the noun (unlike English prepositions which come before).
They show the spatial or relational connection between a noun and the rest of the sentence.
They are '‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•á' ‚Äî they do not change their form regardless of gender, number, or case.
In Marathi, these words attach to the noun: ‡§ü‡•á‡§¨‡§≤ + ‡§µ‡§∞ = ‡§ü‡•á‡§¨‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞ (on the table).
concepts.funFact: In English, prepositions come BEFORE nouns: 'on the table.' In Marathi, postpositions come AFTER nouns: '‡§ü‡•á‡§¨‡§≤ + ‡§µ‡§∞' = '‡§ü‡•á‡§¨‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞.' This is a fundamental difference between Indo-European (English) and Dravidian/Sanskrit-derived languages. Many Indian languages (Hindi, Tamil, Telugu, Kannada) also use postpositions!

concepts.title: Common Marathi Postpositions
concepts.content: Here are the most commonly used ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•á (postpositions) in Marathi with their meanings and usage examples: ‡§µ‡§∞ = on/above; ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä = under/below; ‡§ú‡§µ‡§≥ = near; ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ó‡•á = behind; ‡§™‡•Å‡§¢‡•á = in front of; ‡§Ü‡§§ = inside; ‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•á‡§∞ = outside; ‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§® = from above; ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ç‡§® = from below; ‡§ú‡§µ‡§≥‡•Ç‡§® = from nearby; ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§® = through/from the middle; ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø = without/except; ‡§∏‡§æ‡§†‡•Ä = for; ‡§¨‡§∞‡•ã‡§¨‡§∞ = with/along with; ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§ = until/up to; ‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§® = from.

examples.text: ‡§µ‡§∞ (on/above): '‡§™‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ï ‡§ï‡§™‡§æ‡§ü‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á' ‚Äî The book is on the cupboard.
‡§ñ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä (under/below): '‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§™‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á' ‚Äî The dog is under the bed.
‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ó‡•á (behind): '‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡§æ ‡§ù‡§æ‡§°‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ó‡•á ‡§≤‡§™‡§≤‡§æ' ‚Äî The boy hid behind the tree.
‡§™‡•Å‡§¢‡•á (in front of): '‡§∂‡§æ‡§≥‡•á‡§™‡•Å‡§¢‡•á ‡§ñ‡•á‡§≥‡§æ‡§ö‡•á ‡§Æ‡•à‡§¶‡§æ‡§® ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á' ‚Äî There is a playground in front of the school.

keyPoints: ‡§µ‡§∞ = on/above | ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä = under/below | ‡§ú‡§µ‡§≥ = near | ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ó‡•á = behind | ‡§™‡•Å‡§¢‡•á = in front of
‡§Ü‡§§ = inside | ‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•á‡§∞ = outside | ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§® = through | ‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§® = from above
‡§∏‡§æ‡§†‡•Ä = for (purpose) | ‡§¨‡§∞‡•ã‡§¨‡§∞ = with | ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§ = until/up to | ‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§® = from (starting point)
These words attach directly to the noun in spoken/written Marathi: ‡§ò‡§∞ + ‡§Ü‡§§ = ‡§ò‡§∞‡§æ‡§§ (inside the house).
Mastering postpositions is essential for constructing correct Marathi sentences.
concepts.funFact: Marathi postposition '‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®' (from) and '‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§' (until/up to) are very commonly used in daily speech. For example, '‡§Æ‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¨‡§à‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§® ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§' means 'from Mumbai to Pune' ‚Äî every Maharashtra train or bus announcement uses these two words!

test.question: What methods does the child use to try to get sick in the story?

options.A: Eating spicy food and drinking hot tea
options.B: Eating cold things, standing in rain, and staying up all night
options.C: Running barefoot and jumping in puddles
options.D: Skipping meals and sleeping all day

test.explanation: The child tries classic 'methods' to get sick: eating cold ice cream and icy water, standing barefoot in the rain, and staying up all night near an open window. Despite these determined efforts, the immune system keeps the child perfectly healthy ‚Äî leading to the humorous situation of having to go to school after all.

test.question: What is the correct Marathi translation of 'The cat is under the table'?
test.explanation: '‡§ñ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä' means under/below ‚Äî it is used as a postposition in '‡§ü‡•á‡§¨‡§≤‡§æ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä' (under the table). '‡§µ‡§∞' = on (so ‡§ü‡•á‡§¨‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞ = on the table), '‡§ú‡§µ‡§≥' = near (so ‡§ü‡•á‡§¨‡§≤‡§æ‡§ú‡§µ‡§≥ = near the table), '‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ó‡•á' = behind (so ‡§ü‡•á‡§¨‡§≤‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ó‡•á = behind the table).

test.question: In Marathi grammar, what is a '‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø'?

options.A: A word that describes a verb (adverb)
options.B: A word placed after a noun to show its relationship with other parts of the sentence (postposition)
options.C: A word that names a person or place (noun)
options.D: A word that joins two sentences (conjunction)

test.explanation: A ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø is a postposition ‚Äî a word placed AFTER a noun to show the spatial or relational connection between that noun and the rest of the sentence. Unlike English prepositions (which come before nouns), Marathi postpositions come after: '‡§ü‡•á‡§¨‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞' (on the table), not 'on the table'.

test.question: What does the Marathi postposition '‡§∏‡§æ‡§†‡•Ä' (sathi) mean?
test.explanation: '‡§∏‡§æ‡§†‡•Ä' means 'for' or 'for the purpose of.' Example: '‡§Ü‡§à‡§∏‡§æ‡§†‡•Ä ‡§≠‡•á‡§ü‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ç' = 'a gift for mother.' '‡§∂‡§æ‡§≥‡•á‡§∏‡§æ‡§†‡•Ä ‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§∞' = 'school bag (bag for school).' It is one of the most commonly used Marathi postpositions.

test.question: Which postposition (‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø) would you use to say 'The bird is in front of the house'?
test.explanation: '‡§™‡•Å‡§¢‡•á' means 'in front of.' So 'The bird is in front of the house' = '‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä ‡§ò‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§¢‡•á ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á.' '‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ó‡•á' = behind, '‡§ñ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä' = under, '‡§Ü‡§§' = inside. Knowing direction-related postpositions is essential for describing locations in Marathi.

test.question: What does '‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä' mean in the context of health?

options.B: Immune system / the body's ability to resist disease

test.explanation: '‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä' = ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ (resistance/fighting back) + ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä (power/strength). It literally means 'power of resistance' ‚Äî the immune system. The story shows that the child's immune system is so strong that all the deliberate attempts to get sick fail completely.

test.question: What is the Marathi postposition '‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®' used for?
test.explanation: '‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®' means 'from' ‚Äî showing a starting point. Example: '‡§Æ‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¨‡§à‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§® ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§' = 'from Mumbai to Pune.' '‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®' marks where something starts; '‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§' marks where it ends. Together they are one of the most useful Marathi postposition pairs.

test.question: Translate to Marathi: 'The children are playing outside the school.'
test.explanation: '‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•á‡§∞' means outside. '‡§∂‡§æ‡§≥‡•á‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•á‡§∞' = outside the school (‡§∂‡§æ‡§≥‡§æ + ‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•á‡§∞). So 'The children are playing outside the school' = '‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡•á ‡§∂‡§æ‡§≥‡•á‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•á‡§∞ ‡§ñ‡•á‡§≥‡§§ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á‡§§.' '‡§∂‡§æ‡§≥‡•á‡§§' = inside the school (‡§∂‡§æ‡§≥‡§æ + ‡§Ü‡§§ ‚Üí shortened to '‡§∂‡§æ‡§≥‡•á‡§§'), '‡§∂‡§æ‡§≥‡•á‡§µ‡§∞' = on top of the school (wrong here).

test.question: The humour in '‡§Ü‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§™‡§°‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó' comes from:

options.B: The gap between the child's desperate efforts and the body's stubbornly remaining healthy
options.C: The parents discovering the child's plan and punishing them
options.D: The child actually getting very sick and missing a whole month of school

test.explanation: The irony and humour arise from the huge gap between the child's elaborate, determined efforts to get sick and the body's complete refusal to cooperate. The more desperately the child tries, the more stubbornly healthy they remain ‚Äî a perfect comic situation that all students can relate to.

test.question: In the sentence '‡§™‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ï ‡§ï‡§™‡§æ‡§ü‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á' (The book is on the cupboard), which word is the ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø?
test.explanation: '‡§µ‡§∞' (on/above) is the ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø ‚Äî it is the postposition that joins to '‡§ï‡§™‡§æ‡§ü' (cupboard) to show the spatial relationship. In Marathi, the postposition merges with the noun: ‡§ï‡§™‡§æ‡§ü + ‡§µ‡§∞ = ‡§ï‡§™‡§æ‡§ü‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞ (on the cupboard). '‡§™‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ï' is the noun (subject), '‡§ï‡§™‡§æ‡§ü' is the noun (reference point), and '‡§Ü‡§π‡•á' is the verb.

keyConcepts: ‡§Ü‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§™‡§°‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‚Äî humorous story about trying to get sick to avoid exam
Humour (‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ã‡§¶) as a literary device in Marathi stories
Immune system (‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä) ‚Äî the body's natural defences
‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•á = Postpositions (come AFTER noun, unlike English prepositions)
commonMisconceptions: Students often confuse ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•á (postpositions) with ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§£ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•á (adverbs) ‚Äî both are 'avyaye' but postpositions relate nouns while adverbs describe verbs.
In Marathi, postpositions merge with the noun (‡§ï‡§™‡§æ‡§ü + ‡§µ‡§∞ = ‡§ï‡§™‡§æ‡§ü‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞) ‚Äî students sometimes write them separately, which is incorrect.
Students may think cold weather CAUSES colds ‚Äî the common cold is caused by a virus (rhinovirus), not cold temperature itself.
'‡§Ü‡§§' and '‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á' can both mean 'inside/in' but have slightly different uses ‚Äî '‡§ò‡§∞‡§æ‡§§' (inside the house) and '‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§§' (in the class) both use '‡§Ü‡§§/‡§§' suffix.
realWorldExamples: Exam avoidance is a universal experience ‚Äî this story resonates with every student in Maharashtra and beyond!
Nagpur oranges (‡§∏‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä) ‚Äî Maharashtra's famous immunity booster, rich in Vitamin C.
Maharashtra school exam culture: The SSC Board exams in March are the most feared ‚Äî just like the unnamed exam in the story!
Train announcements in Marathi: '‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§® ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¨‡§à‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§' (from Pune to Mumbai) ‚Äî postpositions in real-world usage.

interactiveElement.title: Unscramble the Word!
interactiveElement.description: Rearrange the letters to form the correct Marathi vocabulary word.

textbookExercise.instructions: Memorize these exam-style answers to maximize scoring in textbook-focused assessments.

qaCards.question: What methods does the child use to try to get sick in the story?
qaCards.answer: The child tries classic 'methods' to get sick: eating cold ice cream and icy water, standing barefoot in the rain, and staying up all night near an open window. Despite these determined efforts, the immune system keeps the child perfectly healthy ‚Äî leading to the humorous situation of having to go to school after all.

qaCards.question: What is the correct Marathi translation of 'The cat is under the table'?
qaCards.answer: '‡§ñ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä' means under/below ‚Äî it is used as a postposition in '‡§ü‡•á‡§¨‡§≤‡§æ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä' (under the table). '‡§µ‡§∞' = on (so ‡§ü‡•á‡§¨‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞ = on the table), '‡§ú‡§µ‡§≥' = near (so ‡§ü‡•á‡§¨‡§≤‡§æ‡§ú‡§µ‡§≥ = near the table), '‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ó‡•á' = behind (so ‡§ü‡•á‡§¨‡§≤‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ó‡•á = behind the table).

qaCards.question: In Marathi grammar, what is a '‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø'?
qaCards.answer: A ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø is a postposition ‚Äî a word placed AFTER a noun to show the spatial or relational connection between that noun and the rest of the sentence. Unlike English prepositions (which come before nouns), Marathi postpositions come after: '‡§ü‡•á‡§¨‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞' (on the table), not 'on the table'.

qaCards.question: What does the Marathi postposition '‡§∏‡§æ‡§†‡•Ä' (sathi) mean?
qaCards.answer: '‡§∏‡§æ‡§†‡•Ä' means 'for' or 'for the purpose of.' Example: '‡§Ü‡§à‡§∏‡§æ‡§†‡•Ä ‡§≠‡•á‡§ü‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ç' = 'a gift for mother.' '‡§∂‡§æ‡§≥‡•á‡§∏‡§æ‡§†‡•Ä ‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§∞' = 'school bag (bag for school).' It is one of the most commonly used Marathi postpositions.

qaCards.question: Which postposition (‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø) would you use to say 'The bird is in front of the house'?
qaCards.answer: '‡§™‡•Å‡§¢‡•á' means 'in front of.' So 'The bird is in front of the house' = '‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä ‡§ò‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§¢‡•á ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á.' '‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ó‡•á' = behind, '‡§ñ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä' = under, '‡§Ü‡§§' = inside. Knowing direction-related postpositions is essential for describing locations in Marathi.

qaCards.question: What does '‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä' mean in the context of health?
qaCards.answer: '‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä' = ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ (resistance/fighting back) + ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä (power/strength). It literally means 'power of resistance' ‚Äî the immune system. The story shows that the child's immune system is so strong that all the deliberate attempts to get sick fail completely.

qaCards.question: What is the Marathi postposition '‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®' used for?
qaCards.answer: '‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®' means 'from' ‚Äî showing a starting point. Example: '‡§Æ‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¨‡§à‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§® ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§' = 'from Mumbai to Pune.' '‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®' marks where something starts; '‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§' marks where it ends. Together they are one of the most useful Marathi postposition pairs.

qaCards.question: Translate to Marathi: 'The children are playing outside the school.'
qaCards.answer: '‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•á‡§∞' means outside. '‡§∂‡§æ‡§≥‡•á‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•á‡§∞' = outside the school (‡§∂‡§æ‡§≥‡§æ + ‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•á‡§∞). So 'The children are playing outside the school' = '‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡•á ‡§∂‡§æ‡§≥‡•á‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•á‡§∞ ‡§ñ‡•á‡§≥‡§§ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á‡§§.' '‡§∂‡§æ‡§≥‡•á‡§§' = inside the school (‡§∂‡§æ‡§≥‡§æ + ‡§Ü‡§§ ‚Üí shortened to '‡§∂‡§æ‡§≥‡•á‡§§'), '‡§∂‡§æ‡§≥‡•á‡§µ‡§∞' = on top of the school (wrong here).

qaCards.question: The humour in '‡§Ü‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§™‡§°‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó' comes from:
qaCards.answer: The irony and humour arise from the huge gap between the child's elaborate, determined efforts to get sick and the body's complete refusal to cooperate. The more desperately the child tries, the more stubbornly healthy they remain ‚Äî a perfect comic situation that all students can relate to.

qaCards.question: In the sentence '‡§™‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ï ‡§ï‡§™‡§æ‡§ü‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á' (The book is on the cupboard), which word is the ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø?
qaCards.answer: '‡§µ‡§∞' (on/above) is the ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø ‚Äî it is the postposition that joins to '‡§ï‡§™‡§æ‡§ü' (cupboard) to show the spatial relationship. In Marathi, the postposition merges with the noun: ‡§ï‡§™‡§æ‡§ü + ‡§µ‡§∞ = ‡§ï‡§™‡§æ‡§ü‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞ (on the cupboard). '‡§™‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ï' is the noun (subject), '‡§ï‡§™‡§æ‡§ü' is the noun (reference point), and '‡§Ü‡§π‡•á' is the verb.

longAnswers.question: What methods does the child use to try to get sick in the story?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: In the story '‡§Ü‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§™‡§°‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó', the child desperately wants to avoid an upcoming exam, so they hatch a plan to intentionally get sick. The child eats cold ice cream, drinks icy water, and stands barefoot in the rain to catch a cold. Furthermore, they sleep near an open window and stay up all night hoping to fall ill. Despite all these extreme efforts, the child's immune system keeps them completely healthy. The humour lies in the fact that the body naturally resists sickness, ruining the child's plan to skip school.
keyPoints: The child wants to get sick to avoid a school exam.
They eat cold ice cream, drink icy water, and stand in the rain.
They stay up all night by an open window.
The body's immune system keeps the child perfectly healthy.

longAnswers.question: What is the correct Marathi translation of 'The cat is under the table'?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: The correct Marathi translation of 'The cat is under the table' is '‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ú‡§∞ ‡§ü‡•á‡§¨‡§≤‡§æ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á'. In Marathi grammar, '‡§ñ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä' is a '‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø' (postposition) which means 'under' or 'below'. Unlike English prepositions that come before the noun, Marathi postpositions are attached to the end of the noun. Therefore, '‡§ü‡•á‡§¨‡§≤' (table) and '‡§ñ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä' (under) merge to form the word '‡§ü‡•á‡§¨‡§≤‡§æ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä'.
keyPoints: The translation is '‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ú‡§∞ ‡§ü‡•á‡§¨‡§≤‡§æ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á'.
'‡§ñ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä' is a Marathi postposition meaning 'under' or 'below'.
In Marathi, postpositions attach to the end of the noun.
The words '‡§ü‡•á‡§¨‡§≤' and '‡§ñ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä' combine to become '‡§ü‡•á‡§¨‡§≤‡§æ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä'.

longAnswers.question: In Marathi grammar, what is a '‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø'?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: In Marathi grammar, a '‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø' is a postposition, which is a word placed after a noun to show its relationship with other words in a sentence. The term itself combines '‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶' (word) and '‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä' (joining). Unlike English prepositions that precede nouns, these words attach directly to the noun in Marathi, such as in the word '‡§ò‡§∞‡§æ‡§§' (‡§ò‡§∞ + ‡§Ü‡§§). Common examples of these postpositions include '‡§µ‡§∞' (on), '‡§ñ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä' (under), '‡§ú‡§µ‡§≥' (near), and '‡§Ü‡§§' (inside).
keyPoints: A '‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø' is a postposition in Marathi grammar.
It is attached after a noun to show a spatial or relational connection.
They merge with the noun, unlike English prepositions.
Common examples are '‡§µ‡§∞', '‡§ñ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä', '‡§ú‡§µ‡§≥', and '‡§Ü‡§§'.

longAnswers.question: What does the Marathi postposition '‡§∏‡§æ‡§†‡•Ä' (sathi) mean?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: The Marathi postposition '‡§∏‡§æ‡§†‡•Ä' (sathi) translates to 'for' or 'for the purpose of' in English. It is a very commonly used '‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø' that attaches to a noun to indicate the beneficiary or purpose of an action. For example, '‡§Ü‡§à‡§∏‡§æ‡§†‡•Ä ‡§≠‡•á‡§ü‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ç' means 'a gift for mother', showing that the gift is intended for her. Similarly, '‡§∂‡§æ‡§≥‡•á‡§∏‡§æ‡§†‡•Ä ‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§∞' means a 'school bag' or 'a bag for school'.
keyPoints: '‡§∏‡§æ‡§†‡•Ä' is a Marathi postposition meaning 'for' or 'for the purpose of'.
It attaches to nouns to show purpose or who something is intended for.
Example: '‡§Ü‡§à‡§∏‡§æ‡§†‡•Ä' means 'for mother'.
Example: '‡§∂‡§æ‡§≥‡•á‡§∏‡§æ‡§†‡•Ä' means 'for school'.

longAnswers.question: What does '‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä' mean in the context of health?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: In the context of health, '‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä' refers to the body's immune system or its natural ability to resist disease. The term is made up of '‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞' meaning resistance, and '‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä' meaning power or strength. A strong immune system fights off harmful bacteria and viruses quickly to maintain health. In the story, the child's '‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä' is so strong that even deliberate attempts to catch a cold by getting wet or eating ice cream completely fail.
keyPoints: '‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä' means the immune system or power of resistance.
It is the body's natural defense against illnesses, viruses, and bacteria.
Good habits like sleeping, eating well, and exercising build this strength.
The story humorously highlights how a healthy immune system fights off forced sickness.

longAnswers.question: What is the Marathi postposition '‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®' used for?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: The Marathi postposition '‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®' is used to indicate the starting point of an action, time, or place, and translates to 'from' in English. It attaches to nouns or pronouns to show origin or separation. It is frequently used together with '‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§' (until/up to) to describe a range or journey. A common real-world example is '‡§Æ‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¨‡§à‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§® ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§', which means 'from Mumbai to Pune'.
keyPoints: '‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®' is a postposition meaning 'from'.
It indicates a starting point in place, time, or origin.
It is often paired with '‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§' to show a complete range.
Example: '‡§Æ‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¨‡§à‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®' means 'from Mumbai'.
